urn:contentItem:5XTB-JY31-JBSN-101N-00000-00Private Briefing: Dealmakers See Strong Pipeline for 20202019-12-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:18:02ZLexisNexisPrivate Briefing: Dealmakers See Strong Pipeline for 2020by Steve Gelsi

Private equity dealmakers predict a robust M&A environment in 2020, despite talk about an economic slowdown, with the middle market expected to outshine mega deals. 

Faced with high buyout prices and crowded auctions for larger acquisitions amid a rising threat of a downturn, GPs continue to find ways to put more capital work. To improve performance and increase returns, firms have: honed their specialties in hot sectors such as healthcare and SaaS; gone down market into the middle market and searched out geographies that may offer more upside than domestic deals; they're also working to increase transparency with their LPs.

Looking back, of the 33 deals that tipped the scales above $10 billion in 2019, private equity firms led only six. These large deals may have stoked dollar volume in sponsor-led M&A, but the real action took place in smaller deals at undisclosed prices. 

Through Dec. 12, The Deal's M&A database tracked 3,548 transactions including add-ons, investments, consortium deals, leveraged buyouts, management buyouts and private acquisitions. That's up from about 3,260 deals under the same search parameters for all of 2018.

To some extent, GPs are simply delivering what their investors want. 

U.S. buyouts of $500 million to $2.5 billion, U.S. small-market buyouts of less than $500 million and U.S. growth capital funds, stand as as the three most desirable sectors out of 23 fund types, according to the Probitas Partners Private Equity Investors Trends 2020 survey results. 

While GPs talked about a potential recession, LPs registered a decline in interest in special situations and distressed debt funds this year, according to the Probitas survey.

Greenfield Geographies Down Market

As more attention focuses on the middle market, dealmakers look to new geographies or for smaller deals that may not attract as much competition as larger, more high-profile exits to deploy capital.

Anacapa Partners LLC's Jeff Stevens, a managing partner, and Ashley Geisler, a managing director said they expect a comparable number of acquisitions in 2020. The firm announced six purchases in 2019 and seven in 2018. 

The growth capital firm seeks out healthy companies in need of a leadership transition, then provides the company with a senior executive to take charge from a cultivated pool of candidates. It looks to partner with healthy companies with $1.5 million to $5 million of Ebitda. Its average entry multiple is about 5.8 times Ebitda and it typically exits its companies at a price of more than 10 times Ebitda, with an average hold period of about five years. 

"Our investment model is focused on working with business owners below the middle market that are looking to make a management transition," Stevens said. "This focus allows us to spend the vast majority of our time working on transactions that are more focused on solving for personal needs/desires and less driven by trying to time the market. The result is more consistent investment activity. [That's]  the reason that we expect 2020 to have similar levels of activity to the previous two years."

The firm just announced three growth equity investment deals in Latin America including https://pipeline.thedeal.com/deals/maa/413112/view.dl|communications platform-as-a-service, company Auronix SA de CV, in Mexico; Agasus SA,   https://pipeline.thedeal.com/tdd/ViewCompany.dl?id=2488137|a hardware-as-a-service (HaaS) provider in Brazil and a growth investment in I4PRO InformÃ¡tica Ltda. (I4PRO),   https://pipeline.thedeal.com/deals/maa/412915/view.dl|an enterprise resource planning software company for the insurance market in Brazil. 

Anacapa's Geisler said the firm will continue to look at Brazil and Mexico for deals. "They're both large, untapped markets," she said. "They also offer us the opportunity to invest in business models that we understand and/or have had success with in the United States but are less developed in these countries."

Boosts From Allocations

Regardless of how the economy performs, LPs continue to turn to private equity and other alternative asset classes to boost returns. 

Christopher McChesney, senior vice president, investor services at Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., sees institutions increasing their allocations to alternatives in 2020. This continues a trend that stretches back several years as returns dwindled in the more other asset classes such as stocks and public debt. 

He expects a strong capital raising environment for GPs in 2020. 

In terms of fundraising what I m hearing from the large GPs, there s still a lot of demand, but you have to customize your offerings for larger investors," McChesney said. "It s getting more complicated. You have big funds with 120 legal entities because every investor is solving to be more tax efficient.

Pressure to increase the efficiency of private markets will drive investments in technology as well as some M&A in the fintech space.

One example is BlackRock Inc. s (BLK) https://pipeline.thedeal.com/deals/maa/406318/view.dl|acquisition of French software company EFrontSAS for $1.3 billion in March, 2019.

"There s a real need to build infrastructure that will make this part of the capital market more efficient, and give investors more control and transparency, McChesney said. There s a wave of substantial tech investment that s starting to  happen."

For 2020, it s possible that some private company valuations may continue to ease back. Even if the economy cools, however, allocations into alternatives won t slow down significantly.  

Private company valuations may come back to reality there will be a little less fairy dust in 2020, McChesney said. Some of those blips and adjustments may affect valuations, but the big picture is clearer in terms of more participation in private markets."

In the global fund space, Brown Brothers Harriman sees a sustained increase in demand for private equity, private credit and real assets. The largest asset managers in Asia are investing in private equity for the first time. Insurance companies are only at 1% or 2% allocations. Allocations still have further to go here in terms of demand, he said. These trends are bigger than the economic cycle and are reshaping the capital formation process, McChesney said.

Silicon Beach Emerges

A.J. Weidhaas, partner, and co-chair of private equity at Goodwin Procter LLP, said his firm has seen strong growth in M&A activity in sponsored 2019. In its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the law firm s deal volume increased by over 15% and it expects comparable growth for the calendar year. 

Among hot sectors, health and wellness deals within the health sector remain plentiful among PE deals. 

Anything that touches on healthy living within the consumer space& any company that focuses on making sure you don t have to go to the doctor we re seeing activity in that space, Weidhaas said. "Within technology, private equity firms continue playing a larger role in the sector as the industry matures and tech is woven into manufacturing, distribution and other areas, he said.

As it looks toward the 2020, the firm eyes more private market M&A activity in Southern California's tech scene as the firm s Silicon Beach office in Santa Monica, Calif., marks its first full year in operation. 

The firm continues to hire lawyers for the office, which is geared toward private equity and the lively tech-sector activity in the area as entrepreneurs from the Bay Area flee to a more early-stage-friendly market with plentiful resources. In 2019, Weidhaas worked on a few Silicon Beach deals including https://pipeline.thedeal.com/deals/maa/405854/view.dl|the sale of L.A.-based Chrome River Technologies Inc., a Great Hill Partners LP portfolio company.

"Silicon Beach looks a lot like Silicon Valley did in the late 1990s building up to the first tech bubble, Weidhaas said. Now Silicon Valley is dominated by the giants in tech and there s a fight for resources such as office space, housing and talent&.Entrepreneurs from companies in Silicon Valley exit one company and move out to start their next venture to places like Silicon Beach, which has a different profile that s less dominated by Big Tech.

2020 Election Causes Some Uncertainty

Overall, 2020 continues to look strong for private equity, Goodwin Procter's Weidhaas said, though things could change with results of the 2020 presidential election.

"The pipeline at this point is not showing any sign of slowing down," Weidhaas said. "We ve got a couple of significant data points coming up as we get into the 2020 election. Those could obviously cut a number of different ways."

The impeachment proceedings on Capitol Hill have already been baked into financial markets, but some uncertainty remains over whether a more left-leaning Democrat such as Elizabeth Warren will win the Democratic nomination. Warren s stated approach to increase regulatory oversight over Wall Street could cause dealmakers to accelerate M&A transactions prior to the election if she were to emerge as the nominee, he said. 

We may see an acceleration of activity in the summer in an otherwise slow cycle if this happens, Weidhaas said. As for whether the long economic expansion that began in 2010 continues, Weidhaas remains cautious but optimistic like other dealmakers. 

There s little doubt in my mind that we re at the tail end of the cycle, Weidhaas said. The question is whether that means we re going to have a significant pullback or hopefully, a more gradual downturn.

urn:contentItem:5Y2N-1BD1-DY5H-1009-00000-00Private Data Claims Public Spotlight;D.C. tries to figure out how to draw the line2020-01-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:18:02ZLexisNexisPg. 2Private Data Claims Public SpotlightD.C. tries to figure out how to draw the linepolicy

The new year has brought new action on the privacy front as states and the federal government try to figure out how to protect user data while allowing it to be monetized to support the free internet content model the country has come to rely on.

The alternative could be a Balkanized internet with sites charging for access and users asked to determine for themselves what information they want to share and when they want to share it.

While access and choice was once the mantra - and access still is - privacy activists are concerned that choice could become a synonym for putting the onus on users to figure it all out. For their part, websites would simply provide transparency about all that collection - likely in slightly larger type or in less Byzantine privacy policies.

Platforms big and small are concerned that if an approach like the tough California privacy law that just went into effect becomes a road map for federal legislation - which many Democrats looking to capture both House and Senate in the fall would like - the free online model could definitely be in trouble.


State and federal officials are looking hard at data privacy concerns.

Amazon is no fan of the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), particularly of its broad definition of personal information. The bill established a consumer right of privacy based on disclosure, the right to opt out of data collection or third-party sharing and the right to have data deleted if a user so chooses.

One site dedicated to providing info on where to find radio stations on the internet (StreamingRadioGuide.com) closed its doors at the end of the year, citing the California privacy law. "I have decided to cease operations rather than face the potential legal threats from the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), which goes into effect at midnight on January 1st, 2020," Fred Stiening, the site's founder, said in a note to former users.

All of that comes against a backdrop of tension and suspicion aimed from inside the Beltway toward Big Tech in general over breaches and data over-sharing and under-informing, not to mention "real" fake news, election ad issues, accusations of bias and attacks from both the right and the left at web platforms' current shield from legal liability over third-party content.

Looking to steer that model toward self-regulation, the Trump administration's National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has released a guide to privacy best practices.

The idea is to continue to get the benefits of data collection while mitigating the privacy risks and avoiding a one-size-fits-all approach, an approach which deregulatory types often associate with "heavy handed" government regulation.

The self-regulatory framework is not binding, but is instead meant to be a tool for privacy-by-design practices that put privacy risks on the same level as other risks.

It is billed as supporting:

"Building customers' trust by supporting ethical decision-making in product and service design or deployment that optimizes beneficial uses of data while minimizing adverse consequences for individuals' privacy and society as a whole;

"Fulfilling current compliance obligations, as well as future-proofing products and services to meet these obligations in a changing technological and policy environment; and

"Facilitating communication about privacy practices with individuals, business partners, assessors and regulators."

NIST said the framework is the result of input from public and privacy stakeholders and the product of three workshops, requests for info and comment, five webinars and hundreds of stakeholder meetings.

urn:contentItem:5XJT-TCD1-F03R-N32H-00000-00Private Equity's Final Profits From Foreclosure Carnage2019-11-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:18:02ZLexisNexisPrivate Equity's Final Profits From Foreclosure CarnageDavid Dayen

Nov 22, 2019( The American Prospect Blogs: http://prospect.org/blogs Delivered by Newstex) Private equity spent the week defending itself, and not all that expertly. Accounting firm Ernst ...ung released a paper[1] funded by the American Investment Council, the industry's chief trade group, with a host of half-truths and misleading statistics, including estimating the annual salary of workers at private equity-owned firms at $71,000 a year by including the executives and the private equity portfolio managers in the equation. Blackstone's Steven Schwarzman took home $786 million[2] in 2018; once you average him in with a bunch of part-time Toys 'R' Us workers, the numbers start to look pretty good.Then, the American Investment Council's CEO touted the Popeye's chicken sandwich[3]—that great invention available only to companies owned by financial managers—as an example of private equity's value to the economy. Companies used to praise themselves for saving lives and connecting the world, now it's for adding a pickle and mayo to fried poultry.

By the way, the same private equity group that owns Popeye's, Brazilian firm 3G Capital, was last seen taking two iconic brands in Kraft and Heinz, merging them, running the company completely into the ground, and walking away[4].Speaking of walking away, private equity just closed a chapter on the opportunity it sought out of the misery of the financial crisis. As millions of families suffered the sting of foreclosure, private equity firms fanned out to distressed areas across the country and scooped up foreclosed properties[5], spending about $100 million a week. They quickly turned over the properties and rented them out, behaving exactly the way you'd expect a Wall Street landlord to: offering substandard and often dangerous rentals with mold and busted pipes, dragging their feet at making repairs, jacking up rents at will, layering on hidden charges, evicting aggressively.After inventing the industry, firms sought to cash out, consolidating the Wall Street rental market into a few firms. Blackstone, the largest private equity firm, was the last, merging Invitation Homes with Starwood Waypoint for an empire of 82,000 homes. On Wednesday, they sold the last of the stock[6], bringing their haul to $7 billion since the 2017 Invitation Homes IPO. That's more than double the initial investment. So Blackstone disrupted rental markets, delivered poor-quality homes to many of the same people who lost theirs in the first place, contributed to the global affordable-housing crisis, according to a U.N. special rapporteur[7], and made off with billions in the process.No wonder those defenses ring hollow. STORY UPDATE WPRI in Rhode Island talked to Senator Sheldon Whitehouse[20] about our story about a bill he co-authored that would encourage deep cuts in mandatory spending. Whitehouse said that he would not support any cuts to Medicare and Medicaid, which is fine, but it's up to the Senate, not just him, after he puts this process in place. 'Our reform bill simply requires the Senate to periodically consider legislation to cut the deficit,' Whitehouse says, and that's the point. Sometimes Republicans will be in charge of government under that requirement, so what Whitehouse personally supports is immaterial. He's creating a monster that will not be under his control. YES, I KNOW Meth, we're on it[21]. SHARING THE WEALTH Speaking of private equity, Alden Global Capital buys another large newspaper group[22], which in the past has meant serious layoffs. urn:contentItem:5WP7-J0W1-JCMN-Y2G3-00000-00Private Equity's Next Leveraged Buyout Might Be the Oval Office2019-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:18:02ZLexisNexisPrivate Equity's Next Leveraged Buyout Might Be the Oval OfficeJeff Hauser Eleanor Eagan

Jul 30, 2019( The American Prospect Blogs: http://prospect.org/blogs Delivered by Newstex) Charlie Neibergall/AP Image Former Vice President Joe Biden speaks in Des Moines.This week's debates are likely to feature explicit attacks on some of America's most well-known and universally hated corporate villains, from Big Pharma and Big Tech to Big Oil and more. As Democrats are forced to pick sides in these fights, however, one other extremely consequential dividing line may be left out of the conversation: the one between candidates fighting to stop private equity and candidates taking the industry's money. A handful of presidential hopefuls are leaving no doubts about where they stand. Earlier this month, Elizabeth Warren, joined by co-sponsors Bernie Sanders and Kirsten Gillibrand, introduced acomprehensive bill[1]that would bring private equity to its knees.

The week prior, Sanders joined arally[2]protesting a private-equity firm's decision to close Philadelphia's Hahnemann University Hospital. Even without legislation, the next president will have many tools to combat the private-equity threat. We have not heard a peep from the other candidates; some appeared in public comments tonot know what private equity is[3]. Taken alone, this silence is puzzling. Combine it with the fact that many of those silent presidential hopefuls are raking in cash from private equity's biggest actors, however, and it starts to look a lot more worrisome.Private-equity bigwigs' support for candidates like Joe Biden, Cory Booker, Pete Buttigieg, and Kamala Harris raises worries that these presidential hopefuls would not make use of the tools at their disposal should they accede to the Oval Office. Worse yet, it suggests that private equity might have a place within their administration. Private equity has savvily avoided being listed in the same breath as other corporate bogeymen. Nonetheless, the industry represents an enormous, multipronged, and rapidly growing threat to everyday Americans. Private-equity firms buy companies with borrowed money and extract value from them to enrich themselves and their investors, whether the company survives or not. Earlier this month, one private-equity firm drew particularly acute outrage when it announced it was closing Philadelphia'sHahnemann University Hospital[4]in order to extract value from its well-located real estate. That, however, is just the tip of the iceberg. When private-equity firms are not closing hospitals, they are acting as adriving force[5]behind surprise medical billing. Or they might be putting you out of a job. According to anew report[6]from the Center for Popular Democracy and the Private Equity Stakeholder Project, PE is responsible for destroying over 600,000 retail jobs in the last ten years, triggering bankruptcies for iconic brands likeToys 'R' Us[7]andSears[8]. Private equity could also be yourlandlord[9], having bought up 200,000 single-family homes during the foreclosure crisis. Unsurprisingly, these firms have made forterrible landlords[10], failing to perform basic maintenance, aggressively increasing rents annually to deliver returns for their investors, and evicting frequently.Private equity might also bedriving up[11]your college tuition costs and lowering the quality of your education. Anew study[12]found that for-profit colleges acquired by private-equity firms see falling graduation rates, earnings, and loan repayment rates. That means more students saddled with debt they cannot repay. Given its villainous profile, it should hardly come as a surprise that the industry is alsoincredibly[13]close[14]to Trump.While private equity's exploits began long before Trump became president, the industry has found a close and lucrative ally in this administration. Numerous formerprivate-equity titans[15]have been tapped to fill powerful roles throughout the executive branch, including Wilbur Ross as Secretary of Commerce and Kenneth Juster on the National Economic Council. Stephen Schwarzman, CEO of Blackstone, the world's largest private-equity firm, is amassive Trump donor[16]and was accordingly appointedchairman[17]of the president's Strategic and Policy Forum. Schwarzman was among those whotagged along[18]for Trump'sfirst overseas trip[19]to Saudi Arabia, and it was while standing in theroyal palace in Riyadh[20]that Blackstone announced it had been picked to manage the country's new$20 billion fund[21]for chiefly American infrastructure investments. These relationships are paying off domestically as well as overseas by way oflooser regulations[22]that make it even easier for private equity to reap enormous profits off the backs of others. Happily, the future president will have broad powers to reverse the Trump administration's actions and to rein in this exploitative industry. That effort would likely start with appointingfinancial regulators[23]who would impose more stringent rules on leveraged lending, a key piece of what makes the private equity model profitable. Executive branch appointees could also target private-equity firms by homing in on the sectors in which they operate. For example, appointees within the Department of Education could require for-profit colleges to demonstrate that the education they provide is of some value, a standard that wouldclose up[24]many private equity-run shops. Motivated and creative appointees throughout the executive branch would undoubtedly find still other ways to limit private equity's predatory exploits. Although a handful of candidates, like Sanders and Warren, seemready[25]for the confrontation, other candidates have been much quieter about the threat posed by private equity. In the meantime, they have been happily accepting the industry's cash. In the second quarter, Joe Biden, Cory Booker, Pete Buttigieg, and Kamala Harris have all received donations from one or both of the leaders of the country's top two private-equity firms, Blackstone and the Carlyle Group. Buttigieg received max donations from 11 high-level Blackstone employees, as well as money from Bain Capital and Neuberger Berman. Biden, Booker, and Gillibrand nabbed donations from employees at at least three of the top 15 private-equity firms. Admittedly, even 11 max donations seems like chump change when top candidates' total fundraising hauls are anywhere from $12 million to $25 million. Many of these donors, however, are not just writing checks, but also collecting them from others on the candidates' behalf. The figures they raise are often consequential. For example,Tony James[26], executive vice chairman at Blackstone, bundled over $100,000 for Hillary Clinton in 2016. This time around, hehosted a fundraiser[27]for Buttigieg in June. Another $100k-plus Clinton bundler (more precise information on Clinton bundlers issadly unavailable[28]), Carlyle Group managing directorJames Attwood[29], gave to Biden, Booker, Buttigieg, Gillibrand, and Harris this quarter. It is possible but unlikely that candidates won the industry's support by offering explicit assurances that they will not undermine the private equity business model. It need not amount to such a clear quid pro quo, however, to be concerning. Candidates' silence on what ought to be a primary target for Democrats is worrisome enough. That is because private equity can get its way through executive branch personnel, an area in which candidates have been asked to make very few public promises, and thus where they face next to no accountability. Private equity could continue to thrive without any changes to the status quo; all they need is confidence that a candidate will not appoint financial regulators intent on rocking the boat. In 2016, for example, Tony James's namesurfaced[30]frequently as a potentialTreasury secretary[31]. Maybe he's hoping for another shot at the seat? Luckily for these candidates, they can address our worries through a couple of simple actions. First, each must end their silence on private equity. Senator Gillibrand, to her credit, has done so by co-sponsoring Warren's bill. Second, just as candidates are expected to address how they will combat the threats posed by Big Tech,Big Pharma[32], and others, they must do so for private equity. That must include being clear about the types of people they plan to appoint to their executive branch and being explicit that private-equity executives will not be among them. If candidates neglect to take these essential steps, however, we will be forced to expect the worst of their future administrations. urn:contentItem:5WCS-5V91-F03R-N3H3-00000-00Private Eyes, They're Watching You2019-06-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:18:02ZLexisNexisPrivate Eyes, They're Watching YouJoseph Hargett

Jun 03, 2019( Banyan Hill: http://banyanhill.com Delivered by Newstex) Big Tech and the government they see your every move. Now these two juggernauts of information are going head-to-head in classic trust-busting fashion.The Wall Street Journal[1]reported over the weekend that the Department of Justice (DOJ) has launched two investigations into Alphabet Inc. (Nasdaq: GOOG[2]) — aka Google — for antitrust violations. Separately,The Washington Post[3]said that the DOJ and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) had divided up territory between Google and Amazon.com Inc.

(Nasdaq: AMZN[4]) — in much the same way you and your uncle discuss who will get the drumstick at Thanksgiving dinner. The implication is clear: the U.S. government is gunning for Big Tech. And it's through playing around. Tech juggernauts like Google, Amazon and Facebook (Nasdaq: FB[5]) (which was surprisingly left off the government's weekend hit list) need to be reined in and given some guidelines. But the secrecy of these government investigations should raise a few more1984-ish hackles. Candidates like Bernie Sanders, D-V.T., and Elizabeth Warren, D-M.A., and even President Trump have called for crackdowns on Big Tech companies. However, the official line from the DOJ and the FTC has been to sit by and wait and allow tech behemoths to become even bigger. They are even considering approving the Sprint/T-Mobile merger. But whatever they were waiting for, they've apparently found it in Amazon and Google. If the DOJ and FTC are getting serious, we could be looking at a battle of the ages: aBrave New Worldv.1984-style battle. The Takeaway: One thing is obvious: If the DOJ and FTC decide to act, it's going to be bad for all FAANG stocks such as Google, Amazon, Facebook and others. While these companies offer extraordinary value for investors, portfolios betting on FAANG stocks are going to see a bumpy ride. What may not be obvious in this Huxley v. Orwell battle is the value of investing in cybersecurity companies. Firms such as Palo Alto Networks Inc. (NYSE: PANW[6]) and Fortinet Inc. (Nasdaq: FTNT[7]). These companies' products not only help keep you safe from unruly hackers, but they can also help protect your data from FAANG and government intrusion. And that's a big plus no matter what happens between the DOJ and Big Tech companies.It was only a matter of time before the big guns in mobile tech came knocking at Advanced Micro Devices Inc.'s (NYSE: AMD[8]) door. The company has the best ultra low power chips on the market, and now Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd. is looking to get a taste. The duo announced amultiyear partnership[9]this morning to roll out mobile graphics in Samsung mobile devices based on AMD Radeon graphics chips. 'We look forward to working with AMD to accelerate innovations in mobile graphics technologies that will help take future mobile computing to the next level,' said Samsung in a statement. This is excellent news for AMD, and yet another reason for investors to jump on the bullish semiconductor bandwagon [Note: link to PRL 'tech boom' promo]. The Bad: Just How Far Down Do You Want to Go?President Trump has the pistols, so he'll get the pesos but Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc. (NYSE: CMG[10])doesn't think that's fair[11]. They'd like to talk it out over a cup of joe. This morning, the burrito baron said that Trump's proposed Mexican tariffs 'could increase costs by $15 million and reduce margins by 20 to 30 basis points.' In a statement, chief financial officer Jack Hartung indicated that prices would rise if the tariffs were made permanent. He said: 'We could also consider passing on these costs through a modest price increase, such as about a nickel on a burrito, which would cover the increased cost without impacting our strong value proposition.' But Chipotle isn't the only one staring down the tariff barrel. Smaller chains like Chuy's Holdings Inc. (Nasdaq: CHUY[12]) could be hurt even more by rising costs. According to analysts at research firm Morningstar, these smaller chains would have trouble hedging against tariffs. Investors might want to put their salsa lessons on hold for now. There's no indication as to how long these tariffs will last. The Ugly: FedEx Hits a Great WallWe've all been there. You're waiting on a package that's supposed to be delivered today. So, you constantly update the FedEx Corp. (NYSE: FDX[13]) website to see where that package is, only to see it has somehow ended up in Timbuktu or Newark (same difference, really). You're mad. You want your package now! What do you do? Well, if you're China, you launch an investigation into wrongful delivery, escalate an international trade war and send FDX stock down sharply on the news. In this case, FedEx accidentally sent crucial Huawei documents to the U.S., instead of to Huawei headquarters. Given the U.S. blacklisting of Huawei, China feels things aren't quite kosher in this situation, and they're taking it out on FedEx. What's more, China is also considering adding FedEx to a list of 'unreliable entities' that could harm Chinese business interests. While the impact to FedEx shouldn't be all that big, the other names that could find their way on to the 'unreliable' list include Qualcomm Inc. (Nasdaq: QCOM[14]), Intel Corp. (Nasdaq: INTC[15]) and Alphabet. Qualcomm is already dealing with a monopoly ruling in the U.S., Alphabet could battle the DOJ soon and Intel is losing market share to AMD. urn:contentItem:5VYH-XSJ1-DYXB-V14S-00000-00Private sector is part of the solution in bioeconomy, experts say2019-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:18:02ZLexisNexisPrivate sector is part of the solution in bioeconomy, experts sayGerardo Fortuna

The private sector has a key role to play in promoting bioeconomy in the agrifood sector, high-level experts have told EURACTIV.com. However, they said the risk of depriving the food production system of organic resources must be weighed up.

The private sector has a key role to play in promoting bioeconomy in the agrifood sector, high-level experts have told EURACTIV.com. However, they said the risk of depriving the food production system of organic resources must be weighed up.

The bio-based private sector contributes 4.2% to Europe's GDP. It generates (EURO)621 billion added value and around (EURO)2 trillion in annual turnover. It also employed 18 million people in 2015, of which more than two-thirds were in agriculture and food manufacturing sectors.

However, the labour productivity gains of agriculture, forestry and fishing remained at (EURO)20,000 per person employed in the 2008-2015 period, below the industry average in other sectors of (EURO)34,000 per person employed.

Launched in 2013, the EU Commission's bioeconomy strategy was initially conceived as a way to encourage the foundation of post-petroleum energy independent Europe. But it soon moved towards solving more cycle problems, including in agriculture and food security.

When it comes to sustainability, people, but governments as well, mainly look at energy, cars, buildings, according to Gerda Verburg, United Nations Secretary-General assistant and coordinator of the UN Scaling up Nutrition (SUN) movement.

"They should pay more attention to agriculture, forestry and fisheries because, in the end, these sectors should keep our planet in healthy conditions to feed the world population," she said.

For Verburg, although it is still work in progress, the bioeconomy concept is an opportunity to "close the circle", especially in the breeding sector where it is possible to fix the problem of greenhouse emissions that animals produce.

The European Commission's new strategy is seeking to create a sustainable bioeconomy and build a carbon-neutral future. Rather than just find a replacement for petroleum-based products, the strategy addresses broader cyclic challenges, including food and nutrition security.

Private sector involvement

Verburg also said big tech companies and the private sector should be involved in all the possible solutions to assist farmers.

Bioeconomy provides a source of additional income from farmers, foresters and fishermen, but it could also be a profitable business for private companies that bring to market services and products.

"I don't care if companies are making profits out of the transfer from a non-sustainable production toward sustainable production," she said, adding that she is much more concerned about companies that continue to push farmers to buy their products.

According to her, it is the fact that some companies are maximising their profits at the cost of people and environment that should raise concerns, rather than the fact that they make use of an innovative approach to support farmers and at the same time develop biodiversity.

"Good for them if they make money out of this, as long as they are part of the solution. And let's be frank, a company who doesn't make profits, also won't make a leap into future," she said.

The private sector is the main actor in all the new agricultural trends, according to Davit Kirvalidze, Georgia's candidate for FAO Directory general and former agriculture minister of his country. Asked by EURACTIV particularly about bioeconomy, he replied, "Empower the private sector, and the private sector will know how to do it".

He added that the private sector had always led the progress while the role of governments is to provide companies with the right regulatory and institutional environment.

Risks

Per Pinstrup-Andersen, a Danish economist and Professor Emeritus at Cornell University, stressed that we "do need to understand much better how to approach all the biological resources used in the bioeconomy framework".

According to him, many risks could come from the use of natural resources for purposes other than food, as has happened with biofuels, which he considers as the wrong way to cope with the energy security problem.

He added that some co-products like animal manure should be kept in the food circle to produce organic fertilisers, rather than be used for energy production.

Animal manure could be treated, indeed, through a process of anaerobic digestion to produce biogas, a renewable fuel which contains methane and that can have an impact in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

"We have to be very careful that we know what we're doing so that we don't simply subtract natural resources from food production with some very negative consequences," Pinstrup-Andersen concluded.

The European Commission put the use of biofertilisers as one of the areas to develop in the context of the new bioeconomy strategy, unveiled last October.

"I would really like to see manure used as a feedstock for fertilisers. It is part of the circular economy philosophy," Commission Vice-President Jyrki Katainen said during the presentation of the strategy.

[Edited by Zoran Radosavljevic]

urn:contentItem:5PPJ-BX71-JBHT-D1W3-00000-00Priya Misra and Scott Galloway interviewed on BB Surveillance.2017-10-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:18:02ZLexisNexisPriya Misra and Scott Galloway interviewed on BB Surveillance.WalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

PRIYA MISRA, HEAD OF GLOBAL RATES STRATEGY, TD SECURITIES; AND SCOTT GALLOWAY, PROFESSOR, NYU STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE

OCTOBER 11, 2017

SPEAKERS: PRIYA MISRA, HEAD OF GLOBAL RATES STRATEGY, TD SECURITIES

SCOTT GALLOWAY, PROFESSOR, NYU STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Let us switch now. We got Andrew Sheets on earlier, a little bit more of an equity angle, here with bonds, Priya Misra is with TD Securities and the head of all of their rates strategy, as well.

Are we in a normal rate environment? The answer is, this has changed, this has changed, this has changed, but your world is still not normal, is it?

PRIYA MISRA, HEAD OF GLOBAL RATES STRATEGY, TD SECURITIES: I think if you try and decompose interest rates into set of central bank expectations and term premium, we're in a new normal over that term premium is concerned. There's a lot of money chasing yield. And so, you know, treasuries at 2.30 are actually pretty cheap if you compare with bunds or -- or you compare with JGB, so I think that's sort of the new normal we're in. When it's very hard, I think, for bond yields to rise even with central banks normalizing, if you got this very large balance sheet and global rates staying low. So I think that's the new normal here.

KEENE: OK. Well, Francine just brought this up, let's pull economics into Priya Misra's world. Bring this up in the wall. This -- we can't send this out the way the (inaudible) are set up. This is the Taylor rule that Francine was showing earlier. And here's the soup (ph) down here. These are the equations that Priya memorized in Bangalore when she took her masters. Here is Nehru right here. Now, that's a Ned Phelps kind of economic number there. What is your belief on the system and the idea that rates could nudge up as Bill Gross talks about when you look at the demographic realities of something like Nehru?

MISRA: I think Nehru is at the (inaudible) in observable quantity. We all tried to estimate it. The Fed, I think, has struggled. The (inaudible) of Nehru significantly.

KEENE: Does it signal lower interest rates sustained, or is Bill Gross right, the great moderation is ebbing away and we may go with higher rates?

MISRA: I'm not entirely convinced that -- that it's -- it's sort of ebbing away. And the -- I guess the main reason is that if -- if you look at structural forces, productivity is very low, wage inflation, despite the fact, you were just talking about juries, the labor market is on fire, we still haven't had any wage inflation, really. So, you know, you're not seeing wage inflation, you're seeing PCE actually head lower, we're estimating we'll continuing to head lower over the next six months. So whatever your estimate of Nehru is, you know, it's probably lower than what we've all thought. And that should mean that the neutral rate for The Fed or where the hiking cycle ends is actually much lower than historical.

So we may see a little bit of ebbing away, I think interest rates can certainly rise, 25-30 basis points, we're not talking a hundred basis points.

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Right. But, Priya, once the Fed hikes, is this now, you know, a stronger sustained trend? And are they right to focus on stability? You can argue that actually a lot of the indicators point to stability and they are preferring that to actually looking at that inflation given what you just said about PCE?

MISRA: Right. That's a fair point. I think we start to struggle with whether that's the reason why the Fed wants to normalize here. There is no reason for the inflation point for them to continue to hike. I think that it's -- it's partly there, but the Fed, I think, at least, under the current leadership does want to focus on sort of macro prudential reasons or -- or -- or tools to actually control financial stability and use monetary policy specifically for the economy, but I think your question becomes very valid once we're at a zero real rate. So once the Fed has normalized, now they've certainly started normalizing the balance sheet, once they think we're at some normal interest rate, not neutral, but normal, I think then the question becomes, what's the catalyst to continue to tighten, you know, maybe financial conditions will -- will become important then. I think that's where Fed leadership becomes significantly important, which we know is -- is entirely influx here.

LACQUA: So what would be the catalyst to tighten, Priya? And is -- and do -- you know, should they worry about distortion, for example, in the markets?

MISRA: You know, I think to an extent, they are still normalizing. I still think that they should use macro prudential tools, now, you know, the tool -- the -- the Fed does have the regulatory site. If they ease that significantly, and certainly with -- with Randy Quarles, with, you know -- if we you see significant easing off of financial regulation, I think then the Fed absolutely should take that into account.

KEENE: Priya Misra with us, and we'll continue this discussion linking in fixed income into the (inaudible), particularly for the markets, and we saw that 22,800 on the Dow yesterday.

(BREAK)

KEENE: Watching on our set, Priya Misra of TD Securities, and within full faith in credit and sovereign debt within the United States, this goes to the opportunity to buy more beleaguered with the stress yield. But I keep hearing this phrase in your literature and others of record tight where the -- the -- the U.S. yield is here or the U.K. yield is here, and things like Catalonia, the yield comes in. Is that still where we are?

MISRA: I think we are. But when it comes to political risk, I think that's very difficult to price. So I'm not sure you're supposed to be buying Spanish bonds just yet. I mean, the market has corrected significantly, we're not at any wide levels for Spain. I mean, if 1.55 is triggered, I think you get a lot more political risk getting priced in, so (inaudible) can still widen up. I think the question is when the ECB comes in, in two weeks, the entire global rate market is actually watching that. Now, if political risk is at its peak, can, you know, Draghi actually tapers, can we talk about rate hikes here? And that is ...

KEENE: If the -- if the E.U. steps in, if the ECB steps in, do you get a whole feeling of this, everything moves up?

MISRA: Yes. I think if they do taper and -- and the question really is not so much the pace of tapering, it's when is the next rate hike. You know, so if they were to taper but they're not hiking until 2019, I think then rates really have a sort of less room to move. But if we're tapering just over the six-month period, I think then bunds came back up and that's taking all treasuries with it, gains with it.

KEENE: OK. Priya Misra with us on the fixed income market.

(BREAK)

KEENE: I want to bring in a book right now, and this is classic Scott Galloway. You got the tuition chart here. The professor from NYU Stern with the cost of college chart, and then he comes over here and he observes, I remind myself that NYU are charging kids $500 a minute for me and a projector. This is ridiculous, he says, and actually uses French a little bit skewed towards -- I can't say that on TV. Now, joining us, Scott Galloway of NYU and, of course, the book is "The Four."

What did you learn in writing the book? A guy as tuned in with you, as wired in as you, when you write about the four big ones, the DNA of Amazon, et cetera, et cetera, what was the observation that surprised you?

SCOTT GALLOWAY, PROFESSOR, NYU STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS: That these countries play by a different set of rules, they're not subject to the same scrutiny, the rest of businesses that we now worship at the altar of innovation versus kindness and character. And there is the way the business is treated and there's the way that innovators and these tech companies are treated.

KEENE: Will that be snapped at one point? There's a lot of tension here right now between on Washington and the -- the glory boys of Silicon Valley, the glory men and women, I should say, of Silicon Valley. Is there a point where those rules will break?

GALLOWAY: Yes, I think the warm has turned, Tom, and I think the breaking point was the weaponization by an intelligence unit of the Russian government of some of these platforms, although I think the regulation or the fines aren't going to come from where we think they're going to come from. I think they're going to come out of the E.U., who registers a lot of the downside that appears around the privacy, some of the job destruction, but a fraction of the upside. We register a lot of benefit here in the U.S. but the E.U. doesn't.

KEENE: You've got great charts in the book that really showed the dominance under some of the metrics here. I love this, follow your talent, not your passion. What is Jeff Bezos' passion?

GALLOWAY: Total and complete world domination. I think we're headed towards a singularity with Amazon. I think the consumer stocks, the S&P 500, the most dominant factor now is no longer interest rates, no longer even the underlying performance of the consumer company itself, but what Amazon is doing or threatening to do. Kroger lost a third of its value in between the time that Amazon announced the acquisition of Whole Foods and when it closed. Amazon threatens to go into the drug -- drug business, and you have drugstores declined 4-5 percent.

I think Amazon can outperform Jedi mind tricks, and that is look at a company, just wish ill on it, and begin inflicting pain without even going into that sector.

LACQUA: Scott, congratulations on the book. I really like Chapter Six. So this Chapter Six is entitled "Light Me." And you say stealing is a core competence of high growth tech firms. This is I.P. but it is also our data.

GALLOWAY: Yes, well, if -- if -- if you think about what these companies have done and what we're saying to these companies, a fine of a hundred and sixteen million dollars, Facebook says to the E.U. Commission, "Don't worry about our ability to share data between WhatsApp that we're trying to acquire and the core platforms, as it's impossible." The -- the acquisition gets approved by the E.U. and then sub-spoiler alert, they figure it out. And the E.U. fines them a hundred and sixteen million dollars on a $19 billion acquisition. This is the equivalent of a 25-cent parking tick for a hundred dollar an hour meter. We have said to these companies that the smart thing to do for shareholder value is to break the law and to lie to us.

LACQUA: Right. And -- and that will -- are you suggesting this will actually continue and there's no, you know, there's no way of avoiding this?

GALLOWAY: Well, I think you're about to see the mother of all fines come out of Europe. The -- the regulator who I would argue whose testicles have descended as Margrethe Vestager. I think she is the only one that is really going after these companies. I don't think the current administration has the will or the collective I.Q. around technology to take on big tech. I think big tech is smarter, has more resources than -- than -- than Washington is able to compete with. I think the -- the regulation, the intervention of fines are going to come out of the E.U.

KEENE: Everybody is reading this book, I kid you not. I see it within our -- our studios here in New York, "The Four" by Scott Galloway, and it is glorious that the TD Securities, Priya Misra, is reading "The Four." Ask your question of Professor Galloway, Priya, after what you've ground through up through chapter this, chapter that.

MISRA: Sure. So I'm not a stock analyst, but I think from a macro perspective, the point that you highlight is very valuable. You're getting these monopolies or oligopolies across industries. I think from a macro standpoint, that's keeping inflation pretty low, but my question from 101 Economics is, at some point, they extract monopoly rent. When does that happen? Right now, Whole Foods has -- has sort of kept -- kept inflation low. At what point does Amazon take over the world and then we start seeing higher inflation?

GALLOWAY: Well, that's a threat, but to your point, we haven't seen it so far, because anti-trust law is largely based on, if it's good for the consumer, we leave them alone. And it's hard to argue these companies haven't been good for the consumer. But when two thirds of all online growth goes to one player, when the third of all retail growth goes to one player, and a hundred and four percent of all digital marketing growth goes to Facebook and Google, meaning, if you're in digital marketing, you don't work for one of those two companies, you join newspapers and magazines and that your business is in structural decline, one wonders what happens when we wake up and we have four to five companies running the consumer economy.

KEENE: We're going to micro economics here in honor to Priya Misra, Priya's question is absolutely brilliant. There's a tip point where you flip from the benefits of Amazon over to it being damaging to the greater industry of any given nation. You and I know, you and I know, it's not a tip point, it's not a single point, it's gradual. And I would suggest, Scott, it will be expressed through the labor economy. What do you see now in the labor economy when I get X number of thousand people lined up in Fall River, Massachusetts to fill cardboard boxes?

GALLOWAY: Well, these companies -- job destructions through innovation is nothing new. We've just never seen companies this good at it. Amazon needs one person for every two or three that Macy's needs to transact the same amount of business. So the -- just the level of job destruction is incredible. And look at -- look at the icons of yesterday, Tom, General Motors, $50 billion in market cap, a quarter of a million, middle-class households been created, Facebook, $450 billion in market cap, 22,000 jobs. So we're under the impression there's a lot more people working at these companies.

The total population of these four companies would -- could fit in the Lower East Side, yet it's got the -- the market capitalization, the size of the GDP of India. So if you want to talk about an outsized valuation relative to the number of people, it's staggering. It's great if you own real estate in Portola Valley, it's great of you work for one of these companies. The question is, is it good for the rest of us?

LACQUA: All right. Scott, the -- the -- you say that basically (inaudible) the European Commission that really wants to go after a lot of these big tech firms in terms of data, but there will be a lot more questions regarding some of the Russia links, as you mentioned briefly, for example, with Facebook. How can the tech firms try to keep Washington at bay?

GALLOWAY: Well, I think there's -- I think it depends on the firm. If I were on the board of Amazon, I would prophylactically spend aid (ph) of U.S. I think they should break themselves up first. I think with all -- generally, the key to all crisis management is to be seen as over correcting, so the series of half measures coming out of Facebook saying they would -- they would hire 250 people and then it's gone to a thousand, which I would affectionately referred to as pissing in the ocean. This is a company that could spend a half a billion dollars on A.I. to identify and flag content, hire 10,000 people and it might reduce their cash flow by 10 percent.

We're talking about not the realm of the possible to stop this but the realm of the profitable. And they're still claiming it would be impossible. Bloomberg wasn't weaponized by Russia, the "New York Times" wasn't weaponized by Russia. They can absolutely figure this out. And they need to skip to that right away.

KEENE: Shout Out to Matt Winkler and John Mickelthwait who helped us not be weaponized by Russia. We're going to continue this conversation with Scott Galloway, let's remember his great work with us, his perspective on Yahoo! and the end of the career for Marissa Mayer. We're going to continue with Priya Misra, TD Securities, with us, Mr. Galloway, the book is "The Four."

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Now, let's get more on the story and the future for Uber with Scott Galloway, he's NYU Stern Marketing professor, he also wrote this great book called "The Four: The Hidden DNA of Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google," and also Priya Misra of TD Securities in New York.

Scott, when you look at Uber, so there's quite a lot of allegations against Uber. What does Uber need to do now to regain public trust, or do they need to regain first of all the trust of regulators?

GALLOWAY: I think they've taken some key steps, the first is replacing the CEO with someone who's seen as sort of, you know, adult supervision. It feels like the board had two great additions which were put on the board by Travis, John Thain, Ursula Burns, two incredibly seasoned executives, but this was a failure on corporate governance. This was incredibly poor behaviour. It became all about the CEO at a point when the company had a lot of shareholders and families dependent upon the well-being of the company. The board is supposed to be adult supervision and (inaudible) and the board has become until now a place where reputations got to die. So get their corporate governance in order, a better CEO, and I think they've -- I think they've done both of those things.

KEENE: You talk about Uber as the fifth horseman, maybe the -- the one that comes on with the four, and then you walk beautifully through the history of Uber. Meghnad Desai at LSE would say one question to Scott Galloway, are they profitable or does profit not matter to the four or to the five?

GALLOWAY: It's a great point, Tom. We've -- Amazon has basically taught the entire ecosystem, that's changed the compact between the market and investors and that it's replaced profits with vision and leadership. And this has snaked all the way back into the private ecosystem. I ran a venture back company. I used to run a venture back company, and the only way I could raise money was if I -- if I promised to lose more money and spend more and grow more.

KEENE: OK. Is that one-off or is the Amazon model of avoiding operating income margins, et cetera, et cetera, is that replicable over to Uber and to others?

GALLOWAY: It appears to be the model that Salesforce is chasing, and I would argue the entire private markets are now have adopted this (inaudible) of grow really fast, established leadership, winner take all regardless of profitability. And it's becoming -- I don't think this -- I don't think this -- this song ends well. But the whole point is grow no matter what the cost.

KEENE: And, Francine, what's critical here -- Francine, what's absolutely critical here is we don't know how this is going to end.

LACQUA: Right. Which was actually my question to Scott, Tom, is that if you say, you don't think this is going to end well, what do you mean with that?

GALLOWAY: Well, and Priya might have some thoughts on this. But the end of the last, you know, the end of the last century, you know, at one point when the markets seized up, there, you know -- then the tide went out, if you -- if -- if, you know, if you will, there are a lot of companies caught very shorthanded. And you could probably go through 80 percent of the C startups right now and they're losing money.

KEENE: I got eight ways to go here. Priya, I'm going to -- jump in here. Is his world like this? Could he write the book, "The Four," because your world's given us money for free? I mean, money for free, right?

MISRA: That's the spare point, yes, I think (inaudible) capital is very low. But it's -- it's a key point, yes, productivity pick up. And I think all this big economy, and people look at what's happening with the four or five and say, look, productivity is pretty high, there's a lot of innovation. So even though the aggregate numbers look low, don't worry, it's actually going to pick up. Well, it may not pick up because the innovation is only happening in these four or five. On an average, I'm not sure productivity is picking up.

KEENE: Two quick questions, is your world good for her India? She's one of the elite of India coming out of their academics. Is the four and the five and the six, India is going to be dominant over China in 20 years. Is your world good for India?

GALLOWAY: What's interesting is if you look at China, the lesson there is don't let these companies in, steal their IPE and then capture the economic value yourself, and you hate to say that. But if you're Italy, do you let these guys in, let them destroy your media, your -- your ad jobs and let a lot of shareholder value flow out, or do you adopt the Chinese model of benchmarking and taking it for yourself?

KEENE: Ten second, Yahoo!'s future?

GALLOWAY: It's -- it's done. It's -- it's where it should be, it's been traded up to a better company and it's going to be, you know, it's going to be a moment in time and that it's done.

KEENE: Scott Galloway, your (inaudible) never going to be winner in New York. It's going to be summer forever, "The Four," there it is, Scott Galloway, New York University. Priya Misra will continue with us. Mr. Galloway has to take Uber downtown to NYU.

(BREAK)

KEENE: Let's get to our single best chart quickly here. Priya Misra of TD Securities, it's the 10-year yield and the great moderation back to 1980. Over here, the two yellow lines are maybe the land of a view of the end of the great moderation. Mr. Gross was here at 2.60 percent as a key indicator, and he brought that down to a key level of 2.4 percent. I know you don't want to parse that narrow, Priya, but the idea of not a lift in rates but just a chronic steadiness of higher rates is of more interest, isn't it?

MISRA: Yes, definitely. We're definitely in that (inaudible), that it's - - it's a lower bend, you know, whether it's (inaudible).

KEENE: And Bill said that as well. He didn't predict Walter Heller rates.

MISRA: So I think the -- the argument for that is that our star or neutral rate is actually much lower. Part of that is inflation, part of that I would argue is even real rates, neutral real rates are lower globally. You're looking at a decline in -- in demographics, you're certainly looking at a decline in productivity that I think is actually far more structured than this idea that we're just not measuring it right, and I think central banks have sort of won the war on inflation, and then some, I think that someone would actually like more inflation than they have. So if you -- you know, this is a global issue -- yes?

LACQUA: So if it's structural, what does that mean?

MISRA: It means that, you know, we'll be perpetually waiting for that productivity lift, so I think central banks will normalize to a point, and then they'll wait for that productivity lift to actually take the -- the -- the funds rate higher, and that's when they struggle. So I think globally, you're seeing this effort towards normalization. That's why the dollar is doing what it's doing. And then I think we're going to be in this band, and you know, potentially waiting for the next recession. But you don't have to have a recession. You can just sort of be at equilibrium at one and a half percent real GDP, for example, for the U.S.

KEENE: A done deal, is December a done deal or do they move it to November? I mean, why not move it to November and get it done with?

MISRA: Well, the market is not at all priced for November. So they have to tell us today in the minutes that they're very close to November. You've got a press -- press conference, you've also got the SEP, so once you get the projections in December and the Fed says, look, we're looking for inflation to pick up, I think they could justify a hike.

KEENE: I'm glad you mentioned that, and we'll look for the minutes this afternoon, and some value. Priya Misra with us with TD Securities, thank you so much. She'll continue with us with David Gura on Bloomberg Radio.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
